_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

EagleClaw Midstream Ventures, LLC (EMV) has a standing commitment to worker and public safety, demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention. These resources include safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the process at the NW Toyah Gas

Processing Facility (NW Toyah), and training of operations personnel and contractors. EMV

implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

EagleClaw places emphasis on prevention, prompt detection, and expeditious correction of unsafe conditions by periodically conducting internal inspections and regularly training responsible personnel. Should a release occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release, and prevent or mitigate any off-site consequences.



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

NW Toyah, located in Reeves County, Texas, is owned by EMV. NW Toyah is a natural gas processing plant comprised of natural gas liquid recovery, natural gas liquids fractionation, and natural gas treatment and compression equipment. Produced gas is delivered to the

NW Toyah Facility via pipeline. The natural gas liquid recovery equipment is designed to recover natural gas liquids from the inlet gas. NW Toyah produces natural gas, and natural gas liquids. The NW Toyah equipment operates to separate, stabilize, compress (gas), dehydrate (gas), store (natural gas liquids), and transfer gas, and natural gas liquids to sales. Natural gas and Natural Gas Liquids are transported by pipeline from NW Toyah.



The listed flammable substance above the threshold quantities at the NW Toyah is a flammable mixture containing methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, 2,2 dimethylpropane, isopentane and pentane. No toxic substances are present in the process. The NW Toyah complies with Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Proce

ss Safety Management (PSM) requirements and Program 1 requirements of the U.S. EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Risk Management Program (RMP). 



General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps Implementation of appropriate administrative and technological safeguards in the process ensure the safety of workers and the surrounding community. The NW Toyah process has been designed using current equipment design codes and standards with appropriate safety controls. The process design includes control systems to maintain operating parameters, such as temperature, pressures, flow, and level within allowable limits. Operating procedures for the process are periodically reviewed for safe operations.



 Personnel operating the process are trained on the operating procedures to familiarize them with the consequences of exceeding allowable safety and operability limits and steps to correct deviation from normal operating parameters. Additionally, EMV has developed maintenance procedures to maintain equipment integrity. 



EMV has implemented safe work practices to help ensure worker and process safety at the East

Toyah. Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel; (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened; (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work); and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures, along with training of involved personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



Specific Prevention Steps

Hazards in the process at NW Toyah are continually managed to ensure safe operations. The accident prevention program is applied throughout the RMP cove

red process at NW Toyah and covers all individually listed flammable substances and regulated flammable mixtures. The prevention program is designed and implemented to prevent accidental releases that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors. Safety features are incorporated into the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of NW Toyah to help prevent, quickly detect, and control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release.



The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:



Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated). 

Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters. 

Total plant emergency shutdown (ESD) system.



Release Mitigation

Portable fire extinguishers.

Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures.

Personal protective equipment.



Five Year Accident History

EMV has an excellent record of accident prevention. NW Toyah is a new facility and has no accident history.



Emergency Response Program Information

EMV maintains written emergency procedures at NW Toyah to protect worker and public safety and the environment. These include procedures for a fire or explosion and notification of local emergency response agencies in the event of an accidental release. Employees are trained on the emergency procedures and the procedures are updated as needed when the process or facility is modified. Changes to the emergency procedures are administered through the Management of

Change process. The overall emergency response program for NW Toyah is coordinated with the Reeves County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Coordination includes periodic meetings to communicate NW Toyah operations, contact information, and response activities. EMV has 24/7 communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., Reeves County LEPC Chairman, Reeves County Sheriff and Pecos Fire Department). The LEPC would assist the Pec

os FD, as requested, to notify the public, control traffic, and facilitate response to an incident. EMV provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated flammable substances at the NW Toyah.
